original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.
simplified: Your dreams can show you ideas about things you did not know you were thinking about. Common dreams, like flying, falling, losing your teeth, or being without clothes in a public place, probably mean similar things to most people. To know what they mean for you, try to link them to events and feelings in your daily life.

original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.
simplified: One very interesting example of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs in Moscow. In Moscow, there are about 35,000 wild dogs on the streets. Some of these dogs were born in the wild, while others used to be pets. Their owners left them. Some dogs live by themselves, and some live in groups. In 2010, scientists looked at the dogs and saw that they have learned to live well in the city. They know it is safer to cross the street with people, and some dogs seem to understand traffic lights.

original: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. Wonder has been a bestseller in the United States and has already won several awards. Many schools are using it as a starting point for discussions about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A film version is being made, and many, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.
simplified: Wonder is a book by RJ Palacio, who lives in New York. She got the idea for the book after she saw a girl with a face that looked different. Wonder is very popular in the United States and has won a few awards. Many schools use it to talk about bullying, friendship, and being different. A movie of the book is being made, and many people, including me, are excited to see what RJ Palacio writes next.

original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.
simplified: Chloe has two pet rats named Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows that rats are not usual pets. She has explained many times to people that rats are not dirty. She tells them rats are great pets if you take care of them well. But she understands why some people do not like rats. She also did not like rats at first. Then her friend Martin showed her his pet rats, and she saw they were friendly and smart. Last year, one of Martin's rats had babies, and Chloe decided she wanted two of the baby rats.

original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.
simplified: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some baboons have been hurt or killed in car accidents, and some have been shocked by electricity when they touched electric wires while playing. Baboons are a protected animal because there are not many of them left. To help baboons and stop problems between people and baboons, the city has hired Baboon Monitors. These people have the job of chasing baboons out of the city or catching them and letting them go in the countryside. This plan has worked a little, but it is hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city because they think it is an easy place to find food.

original: I work for a global IT company, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making idle chit-chat with colleagues. I work on a project basis, and this flexibility is very valuable to me because it means that I can easily take some time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. The downside is that without clear office hours, I tend to work well into the evening, sometimes skipping dinner to finish a task.
simplified: I work for a big IT company, but their main office is in the United States. So, I do all my work online from home. This means I don't spend time traveling to work or talking too much with other workers. I work on different projects, and this is good for me because I can take time off easily. I can go to my children's school shows or see the dentist when I need to. The bad part is that, without set office hours, I often work late into the evening and sometimes miss dinner to do my work.

original: In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to make political points and produced art that tried to make people think about war, inequality and discrimination. Other street artists were more concerned with producing beautiful, attractive work. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas adding colour, life and beauty to grey, city walls.
simplified: In the 1990s, people kept doing graffiti, but street art became very popular all over the world. Some artists wanted to show political ideas and made art to make people think about war, unfairness, and being treated differently. Other street artists wanted to make art that was just beautiful to look at. In South America, many street artists worked in poor areas to make the grey city walls more colorful and beautiful.

original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it is easy for customers to buy without thinking, while major brands offer such cheap clothes that they can be treated like disposable items – worn two or three times and then thrown away.
simplified: Every day, people see many things to buy on social media, in magazines, and in shop windows. British people are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping makes it easy to buy things without much thought. Big brands sell clothes so cheaply that people can wear them a few times and then throw them away.

original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr, Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning ruddy in the June sun. Otherwise he had the indoor tan of a man that made money while other people did the work.
simplified: Sam looked at the car coming up to the Big House. It made a trail of dust. The horses moved their tails to chase away flies. They didn't care that their owner was visiting after ten months. Sam was waiting. Mr. Carter only came here when he needed to, and Sam liked it that way. If Sam stayed out of his boss's way, he could keep his job longer. Mr. Carter wiped sweat from his neck. Sweat marks on his shirt looked like shapes on a map. His skin was turning red in the June sun, but he usually looked like someone who worked inside and earned money while others did the hard work.

original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.
simplified: In Berlin, Germany, many people in the city were unhappy about hunters shooting pigs. They thought it was cruel. Because of this, there were many arguments between hunters and people who love animals. The city council listened to the protests and decided to try a kinder way to deal with pigs. They will not shoot the pigs anymore. Instead, they are putting up fences and have made it illegal to feed the pigs. We will see if this plan works. There might be more pigs now because winters are not as cold as before.

original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.
simplified: A big idea for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of old Greek stories. When she was a child, one of her favorite stories was about Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story, the city of Athens had to follow the rules of Crete, but the people of Athens did not like it. As a punishment, King Minos of Crete made the people of Athens send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The young people were put in a maze and eaten by a monster called the Minotaur. But one of the young people, named Theseus, fought the Minotaur and killed it. Suzanne thinks Katniss Everdeen in her book is like a new version of Theseus.

original: By bringing people and animals together, zoos have the potential to educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe environment for animals which have been mistreated in circuses, or pets which have been abandoned. Zoos also carry out important research into subjects like animal behaviour and how to treat illnesses.
simplified: Zoos bring people and animals together. They can teach people about saving animals and their homes. Some zoos help animals that were hurt in circuses or left behind as pets. Zoos also study how animals act and how to make them healthy.

original: A different trend is springing up in opposition to consumerism – the 'buy nothing' trend. The idea originated in Canada in the early 1990s and then moved to the US, where it became a rejection of the overspending and overconsumption of Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day people organise various types of protests and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organise the exchange and repair of items they already own.
simplified: A new idea is growing that is against buying too much – it's called the 'buy nothing' trend. This idea started in Canada in the early 1990s and then went to the US. It is about saying no to spending too much money and buying too many things during Black Friday and Cyber Monday on the Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day, people protest and even cut up their credit cards. During the year, Buy Nothing groups help people swap and fix things they already have.

original: Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is considered vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.
simplified: Is graffiti art or is it vandalism? This depends on what you think. But in many countries, writing or painting on things you don't own is called vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police, and some have had to pay money as a fine. Many city councils say it costs a lot to clean graffiti from buildings, buses, and trains.

original: What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Recently, there has been a growing recognition of its value as an art form. There have been major exhibitions of street art in galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organised a street art exhibition at a New York gallery in 2008. She defended street artists, saying 'artists who paint on the street are merely expressing themselves, not hurting anyone. They should be appreciated and celebrated'.
simplified: What do people in the art world think about graffiti and street art? Recently, more people are starting to see it as important art. Big art shows for street art have happened in galleries in Paris, London, and Los Angeles. An American artist named Elura Emerald set up a street art show in a New York gallery in 2008. She said street artists are just showing their feelings and not hurting anyone. She believes they should be liked and celebrated.

original: If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.
simplified: Most people have four to six dreams every night after they are ten years old. This means they can have about 2,000 dreams each year. When a person is 80 years old, they might have had around 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 percent of our dreams, we still remember a few thousand dreams in our life. It's not hard to believe that sometimes a dream is followed by a real event that is similar to it, especially if the dream is about something that often happens in daily life.

original: The Hunger Games takes place in the future, after the destruction of North America. The country is called Panem and is made up of twelve poor districts governed by the wealthy Capitol. The Capitol holds absolute power over the nation. Each district is responsible for producing different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story begins, provides all the coal for the country. There used to be a thirteenth district but they rebelled against the Capitol in the past and were destroyed.
simplified: The Hunger Games happens in the future, after North America is destroyed. The new country is called Panem. Panem has twelve poor areas called districts. A rich city called the Capitol controls everything. Every district makes different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story starts, gives coal to the country. There was once a thirteenth district, but it fought against the Capitol and is now gone.

original: Often wild animals come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into residential areas on the edge of the city to feed. They open rubbish bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons have even come into people's houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked a lot of pet animals, so understandably, many city residents don't welcome their presence.
simplified: Sometimes wild animals go into cities to find food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming to areas where people live at the edge of the city. They open trash cans and eat fruit from gardens. Some brave baboons even go into houses and take food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked many pets, so many people in the city do not like having them around.

original: A large number of bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often due to an error made by the engineers, such as a miscalculation. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers on it at the time.
simplified: Many accidents happen when people are building a bridge. These accidents often happen because the engineers make a mistake, like calculating something wrong. The bridge can fall down because of its own weight, and this can be very dangerous for the workers on it.

original: George Lucas was one of the early film directors to directly base his story on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Typically the hero starts the story living an ordinary life, but something happens that calls them to an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives an ordinary life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure' that starts the hero on his journey.
simplified: George Lucas was one of the first movie directors to use the 17 stages of the hero's journey in his story. The story usually starts with the hero living a normal life. But then something happens, and the hero is called to go on an adventure that changes everything. At the start of Star Wars, Luke is living a normal life with his aunt and uncle and he fixes robots. When he finds a message from Princess Leia to Obi-Wan Kenobi in the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure'. This is the start of the hero's journey.

original: Another suggested defence against a PHA on course to hit Earth is to blow it up using a nuclear weapon. It may sound like a plot from a film, and it was the subject of the 1998 film Armageddon, but the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a genuine NASA proposal. The eight-ton rockets would be fired at an approaching asteroid with the hope of bumping it off course. If the asteroid was too close to Earth for this plan to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.
simplified: One idea to stop a large asteroid from hitting Earth is to use a nuclear weapon to destroy it. This might sound like a movie story, and it was a movie called Armageddon in 1998, but NASA has a real plan like this. This plan is called HAMMER. It involves rockets that weigh eight tons. These rockets would fly to the asteroid and try to push it away from its path. If the asteroid is too close to Earth, the rockets would have nuclear bombs to destroy the asteroid instead.

original: According to Campbell, the hero at first refuses the call to adventure, but a mentor appears who helps them and they decide to 'cross the threshold' and travel into the 'special world' where the adventure happens. The next stage consists of passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends as the hero prepares to face their biggest challenge. For Luke the mentor is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO and the enemy is Darth Vader inside the special world of the Death Star.
simplified: Campbell says that at first, the hero does not want to go on an adventure. But then a wise person, called a mentor, helps the hero, who decides to go on the adventure. The hero goes into a new and special place where the adventure happens. Next, the hero must pass tests, fight bad people, and meet new friends to get ready for a big challenge. For Luke, the wise mentor is Obi-Wan, his friends are Han Solo, R2D2, and C3PO, and the bad guy is Darth Vader in the special place called the Death Star.

original: Underutilised items may seem useless to some, but could be an asset to others. With the advent of the internet, online communities have figured out a way to generate profit from the sharing of those underused assets. Using websites and social media groups that facilitate the buying and selling of second-hand goods, it is now easier than ever for peer-to-peer sharing activities to take place. And this is known as the sharing economy.
simplified: Some things that people do not use a lot might not be useful to them, but they can be helpful to others. With the internet, people have found a way to make money by sharing these items. By using websites and social media groups to buy and sell used items, it is now easier for people to share with each other. This is called the sharing economy.

original: Around the 18th and 19th centuries two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams represent things hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other theory was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a collection of random activity in the brain while it's organising memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and put them into some sort of story.
simplified: In the 18th and 19th centuries, there were two main ideas about dreams. One idea was that our dreams show things that are hidden in our mind. Freud thought that if we can understand our dreams, we can understand our hidden feelings and problems. The other idea was different. It said that dreams are just random things in our brain when it is organising memories and things from the day. When we wake up, we try to understand these random pictures and feelings and make a story from them.

original: I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many distractions around: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for various things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.
simplified: I work for myself, so I am my own boss. This is good because I decide what to do and how to use my time. At first, I worked from home, but it was difficult to focus. There were many things distracting me: chores at home, making another cup of tea, and my family wanting my attention. I tried working in a nearby café, but the Wi-Fi was not good and I drank too much coffee. Finally, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other people like me. I enjoyed getting dressed to go to work and concentrating better in an office.

original: Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. If it did get the money, it could probably achieve its goal in ten years. Once logged, the planetary defence team would still need to work out how to defend the planet against being hit by the truly worrying asteroids – the PHAs.
simplified: NASA wants to find middle-sized rocks in space, called near-Earth objects (NEOs). To do this, they need money to make a new space telescope called NEOCam. This telescope would use a special kind of light, called infrared, to see the rocks. If they get the money, they can find these rocks in ten years. After they find them, they still need to learn how to stop the really dangerous rocks, called PHAs, from hitting Earth.

original: The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or things for the house. For the next stage, they gave up services, for example haircuts, eating out at restaurants or buying petrol for their cars. In one year, they'd saved $55,000.
simplified: The 'buy nothing' idea is popular with influencers on social media. Influencers usually talk about clothes and make-up to buy. Now, some people on YouTube tell their viewers not to buy anything for a long time, even a year. Two friends in Canada tried to spend money only on food for one year. In the first three months, they stopped buying things like electronics, clothes, or house items. Next, they stopped using services like haircuts, eating at restaurants, or buying gasoline for their cars. In one year, they saved $55,000.

original: Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is curious about other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi declares himself to be simultaneously Hindu, Muslim and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one religion, Pi refuses, saying 'I just want to love God'. From that moment, his family and teachers decide to let him make his own mind up about religion.
simplified: Religion is important to Pi. His family is Hindu, but he wants to learn about other religions. He becomes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. Pi surprises everyone by saying he is Hindu, Muslim, and Christian at the same time. When his family and teachers ask him to choose only one religion, Pi says, 'I just want to love God.' After that, his family and teachers let him choose his own religion.

original: Some people think writing your dreams down can open your mind to lucid dreaming. Lucid dreams are dreams where you're not only aware you're dreaming but you can make decisions to affect the events of your dreams. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can direct the plot of your dream like a film director. Then, instead of just working out the meaning of your dreams, you'll be creating them, though you might want to continue having some dreams that allow your subconscious to tell you what's on your mind!
simplified: Some people believe that writing down your dreams can help you have lucid dreams. Lucid dreams are dreams where you know you are dreaming, and you can decide what happens in the dream. For example, you can change a bad dream into a good one, or you can decide what happens in the dream like a director makes a movie. Instead of just thinking about what your dreams mean, you will be making them. But you might still want to have some dreams that help your mind show you what you are thinking about!

original: People might not realise they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they donate their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those unwanted clothes. 'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in and is often too poor quality to recycle; people don't want to buy it second-hand. Huge quantities end up being thrown away, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad, causing even more economic and environmental problems.
simplified: People might not know they are adding to the problem of throwaway clothes because they give their old clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all these clothes. 'Fast fashion' becomes old-fashioned very quickly and often isn't good enough to recycle; people don't want to buy it used. So, a lot of clothes get thrown away, and many clothes charities can't sell are sent to other countries, making more economic and environmental problems.

original: Not content with one amazing trip, some of today's adventurers go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, ridden a bike across Canada and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.
simplified: Some people like to do many adventurous things. Meagan McGrath from Canada is one of them. She has done many difficult things: she climbed the tallest mountain on each continent, rode a bike across Canada, and ran a race in the Sahara Desert where it was very hot. But maybe her most amazing adventure was skiing to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a big hole made of ice and needed help to get out. Many people would stop after that, but Meagan continued. She reached the South Pole forty days later. She pulled a sledge with her tent and food through very cold weather and ice storms.

original: Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage residents to think about the problem of homelessness.
simplified: Blek le Rat began by painting rats on the walls in Paris, where he lived. Now, he wants people to think about social problems and issues. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities. This is to make people think about the problem of homelessness.

original: In some areas, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. Taiwan is one such place and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city council has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the city's subway trains.
simplified: In some places, local governments have tried to stop artists from painting graffiti on any wall they see. They do this by giving special places for graffiti. Taiwan is one of these places, and it has 'graffiti zones' where artists can paint and write on walls freely. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city government has even let some graffiti artists paint on the subway trains.

original: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to explore different locations. Her work is found on pavements, in empty factories and on abandoned cars. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. For her, this reflects how life is full of change with its cycle of endings and new beginnings.
simplified: Faith47 is from Cape Town, South Africa. She paints large, colorful pictures of people and animals. She likes to paint in different places. You can find her art on sidewalks, in empty buildings, and on old cars. She likes that street art does not last forever. The weather or city cleaners will take it away soon. For Faith47, this shows that life changes. There are endings and new beginnings.

original: In her previous work environment, Gabriela was used to a high power distance culture where power and authority are respected and everyone has their rightful place. In such a culture, leaders make the big decisions and are not often challenged. Her Swedish team, however, were used to working in a low power distance culture where subordinates often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as coaches or mentors who encourage independent thought and expect to be challenged.
simplified: In her old job, Gabriela was used to working in a place where bosses have much power and everyone knows their place. There, only the leaders make important decisions and people do not usually question them. But in her Swedish team, people were used to working differently. Here, workers often help their bosses, and together, they find answers and make decisions. Leaders here are like coaches who want people to think for themselves and are okay with being questioned.

original: When Gabriela became aware of the cultural differences between her and her team, she took the initiative to have an open conversation with them about their feelings about her leadership. Pleased to be asked for their thoughts, Gabriela's team openly expressed that they were not used to being told what to do. They enjoyed having more room for initiative and creative freedom. When she told her team exactly what she needed them to do, they felt that she didn't trust them to do their job well. They realised that Gabriela was taking it personally when they tried to challenge or make changes to her decisions, and were able to explain that it was how they'd always worked.
simplified: When Gabriela found out that she and her team had different cultures, she decided to talk with them about how they felt about her way of leading. Her team was happy that she wanted to know their opinions. They said they liked working with freedom and making their own choices, instead of just doing what she told them. When Gabriela gave strict instructions, the team felt she did not trust them to do their work well. They understood that Gabriela got upset when they questioned her decisions or wanted to change them. They explained that this was their normal way of working.

original: Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.
simplified: Os Gêmeos are twin brothers from São Paulo. They are artists and they paint many things. They make small tags and big, colorful pictures of people on buildings. Their art is very big, so they use cranes to help them. In 2007, they painted a whole castle in Scotland.

original: People have been painting and writing on walls throughout history. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe used to paint pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists have found numerous examples of graffiti written in Latin. original: Gary Collins, an off-duty policeman, was watching the London riots on TV. He immediately recognised several people and cut his holiday short to help with identification. He ended up spending six months going through the CCTV film and managed to identify 190 people, many from their eyes alone. His help was of decisive importance in the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of footage, facial recognition software managed to identify just one person.
simplified: Gary Collins is a policeman who was not working, but he was watching the London riots on TV. He saw some people he knew and decided to stop his holiday to help the police. He spent six months looking at CCTV videos and was able to recognize 190 people, sometimes just by looking at their eyes. His help was very important for the investigation. There were 200,000 hours of videos, but the facial recognition software only found one person.

original: Personally, I think it's fascinating to consider how we'll speed up our evolution as a species by augmenting our bodies. Imagine if you could implant a computer inside our brain! Soon we'll be able to do just that and enhance our mathematical ability, audiovisual perception and our memory, and this idea is only going to become more and more commonplace.
simplified: I think it is interesting to think about how we can change as humans by adding new technology to our bodies. Imagine if we could put a computer in our brain! Soon, we will be able to do this and improve how good we are at math, seeing and hearing, and remembering things. This idea will become more and more normal.

original: It was a fascinating talk and the speaker really hit the nail on the head with a couple of things. Take parental influence, for instance. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing their homework when they witness their parents posting on social media while cooking the evening meal or waiting at a red light? She also made a valid point about people wanting to be in two or several places at once. So they switch back and forth between their real-life and online conversations. I see it all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They arrange to meet and then sit together in silence while each one engages in a different conversation online.
simplified: The talk was very interesting, and the speaker made some good points. One example is about how parents influence teenagers. How can we expect teenagers not to text when doing homework if they see their parents using social media while cooking or waiting at a red light? The speaker also talked about how people want to be in many places at the same time. So, they keep switching between talking in real life and online. I see this with my teenage daughter and her friends. They plan to meet, but then they sit together quietly while each person talks to someone else online.

original: As for news stories that make us think the world is an increasingly violent place, there is cause for some optimism too. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but countries are mostly co-existing more peacefully than in the past. However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, though, the statistics are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of violent crime than political conflict, the global murder rate fell slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.
simplified: Some news stories make us think the world is more violent now. But there is some good news too. After World War II and until 1990, there were 30 wars, each killing over 100,000 people. Now, there are still wars, but countries live more peacefully together. Terrorism has increased in recent years, and since World War II, more civilians have died in wars than soldiers. However, not all news is bad for civilians. People are more likely to die from violent crime than from political conflict, but the murder rate around the world went down from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.

original: Wasfia has dedicated her life to supporting human rights and has witnessed numerous international humanitarian projects in her homeland to educate and train women and girls, but once too often they have been left with nothing when such projects have stopped running. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself and so she brought together two of her passions, mountaineering and human rights, in order to try and change attitudes towards women in her country. She originally took up climbing while working on humanitarian campaigns in Tibet and Nepal, as in a coastal, primarily flat country like Bangladesh most people have never set eyes on a mountain. Her campaign seems to be doing the trick as fellow countrymen and women are sitting up and taking notice along with the rest of the world.
simplified: Wasfia has spent her life helping people with human rights. She worked on many projects in her country to help teach and train women and girls. But often, these projects ended, and the women were left with nothing. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to support itself. So, she combined her two passions: climbing mountains and human rights, to try and change how people think about women in her country. She started climbing when she was working in Tibet and Nepal. These places have many mountains, but Bangladesh is mostly flat with the ocean, and people there are not used to mountains. Wasfia's campaign is working because now people in her country and around the world are paying attention.

original: The majority of people believe that developing countries are in a terrible situation: suffering from incredible poverty, governed by dictators and with little hope for any meaningful change. But, surprisingly, this is far from the truth. The reality is that a great transformation is occurring. Over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and come out of poverty. Additionally, six million fewer children die every year from disease, millions more girls are in school and millions of people have access to clean water.
simplified: Most people think that developing countries have very big problems. They believe these countries are very poor, have bad leaders, and cannot change. But this is not true. Big changes are happening. In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people now have more money and are not poor anymore. Also, six million fewer children die each year from sickness. Many more girls go to school, and many people now have clean water.

original: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when feedback becomes such a routine, employees can start to perceive positive feedback as simply a form of sugarcoating the negatives, thus diminishing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered so as to reinforce and encourage good performance.
simplified: Many managers try to make giving feedback nicer by putting negative feedback between two positive comments. But when this happens often, employees might think that positive feedback is just there to make the negative feedback feel less bad. This makes positive feedback feel less important. Instead, managers should give positive feedback to support and praise good work, not just to make negative feedback easier to hear.

original: I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Forget the movie image of a terrifying Terminator stamping on human skulls and think of what's happening right now: military machines like drones, gun turrets and sentry robots are already being used to kill with very little human input. The next step will be autonomous 'murderbots', following orders but ultimately deciding who to kill on their own. It seems clear to me that this would be completely unethical and dangerous for humanity. We need to be very cautious indeed about what we ask machines to do.
simplified: I am part of a group trying to stop killer robots. Forget about the scary robots from movies. Think about what's happening now: machines like drones, gun turrets, and guard robots are used in the military and can kill with little help from people. The next step might be robots that decide who to kill by themselves. I think this is very wrong and unsafe for people. We need to be careful about what we let machines do.

original: Overall, more people are learning English than the other languages combined and English is spoken in the highest number of countries. However, Chinese has by far the greatest number of native speakers. There seems to be little correlation between how many native speakers there are of a language and the number of learners, but there is a stronger link between the number of learners and how many countries have speakers.
simplified: Many people are learning English. It is spoken in the most countries. But, Chinese has the most people who speak it as their first language. The number of people learning a language is not connected to how many native speakers it has. But, the number of learners is more connected to how many countries speak the language.

original: Your manager stops you and says she needs to have a word about your performance in the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. When you step into her office on Monday morning she begins by praising you for the good work you've done on the project, and you wonder if this is the obligatory praise that starts off the typical 'feedback sandwich'. You know how the feedback sandwich goes: say something nice, say what you really want to say, say something nice again.
simplified: Your manager talks to you and says she wants to discuss your work on the recent project. You feel worried all weekend and think about what mistakes you might have made. On Monday morning, you go to her office. She starts by saying nice things about your work on the project. You wonder if this is just the usual nice words before you hear the real feedback. You know the feedback sandwich: say something nice, then the real feedback, then something nice again.

original: A fast-paced, foot-tapping rock album, Born in the USA's lyrics nevertheless carry emotional weight. Behind the catchy rock melodies that drive these powerhouse classics are stories of the dark side of the American dream. Many tracks deal with the struggles of hard-working ordinary people and the bitterness and anger they feel as life doesn't bring them riches or glory. The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job. It's not hard to imagine that the artist is channelling real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become a star. The album will leave you in no doubt of the unique and extraordinary talent of the Boss.
simplified: The album 'Born in the USA' is made up of rock songs with fast and exciting music. But the words in these songs are full of feelings. The songs talk about the difficult parts of living in America. Many songs are about hard-working people who feel upset because life is not giving them money or success. For example, the song 'Glory Days' is about people in a small town who think about when they were young and happy. Another song, 'Downbound Train,' tells the story of a young man who loses his job and his life becomes difficult. It seems like the artist sings about real people he knew and what his life could have been like if he didn't become famous. This album shows how special and talented 'the Boss' is.

original: Lewis would like to see the number of marine protected areas in the world increase from 3 per cent to 10 per cent in an attempt to reverse the damage caused by human activity such as overfishing, polluting and littering. During his expeditions, Lewis has witnessed this environmental destruction first-hand. He's swum over coral reefs bleached by the increase in water temperature, and observed underwater deserts beneath the shallow waters of the Red Sea, devoid of life and strewn with plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have an unsolvable problem on our hands.
simplified: Lewis wants more areas of the sea to be protected. Right now, only 3 percent of the sea is protected, and he wants it to be 10 percent. He believes this will help fix the damage people have done, like catching too many fish, throwing trash in the sea, and making the water dirty. Lewis has seen this damage when he travels. He has swum over coral reefs that turned white because the water is too warm. He has also seen places in the Red Sea with no fish and lots of plastic. Pugh thinks nature can get better if we create safe spaces for it, but we need to hurry. If we don’t take care of the sea now, the problems might become too big to fix.

original: Best-selling author Terrie Sharp knows how to tell a good story or two, having twice won the Olive Crime Writer Award. Born on the housing estate with the highest crime rate in Glasgow, she learned to keep quiet, stay out of trouble and how to open car doors with a knife. Luckily, she only used her knowledge to write her novels and she's not so quiet these days, appearing on popular daytime shows like Police Today and at writing conferences throughout the UK.
simplified: Terrie Sharp is a famous writer who tells great stories. She has won the Olive Crime Writer Award two times. Terrie grew up in a place in Glasgow where there was a lot of crime. She learned to stay quiet, avoid trouble, and open car doors with a knife. But she only used her skills for her books. Now, she talks a lot on TV shows like Police Today and goes to writing meetings in the UK.

original: Are things getting worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science are under attack. When commentators and demagogues appeal to people's tribalism, fatalism and distrust, then we are in danger of causing irreparable damage to important institutions like democracy and world co-operation.
simplified: Is everything getting worse every day? Is getting better impossible? In a book called 'Enlightenment Now,' Steven Pinker talks about how humans have gotten better and sees good news. We live longer, healthier, and are happier. We also have more freedom. The real problem, Pinker says, is that people do not like reason and science as much anymore. When leaders or people on TV try to make us afraid or make us fight each other, we might damage important things like democracy and working with other countries.

original: In older horror films, when protagonists were in desperation, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less believable now. What's the solution to maintain suspense? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to call for help, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.
simplified: In old horror movies, the main characters could not call for help or the police when they were in trouble. Today, mobile phones can make this less believable. So, how do filmmakers keep the suspense? No phone signal! If you are a hero in a horror film, it's very likely that when you really need to call for help, you will not have phone signal. Or your phone battery will die when you try to call. Sometimes both happen.

original: In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. And now it's happening again to Big Mike's successor – the Cavendish. With its easily transported, thick-skinned and sweet-tasting fruit, the Gros Michel banana plant dominated the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the main grower and exporter in South America at the time, mass-produced its bananas in the most efficient way possible: it cloned shoots from the stems of plants instead of growing plants from seeds, and cultivated them in densely packed fields.
simplified: In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America had a big problem. Their best banana, called the Gros Michel or Big Mike, was dying. Now, the same thing is happening to the banana that came after Big Mike, called the Cavendish. The Gros Michel had a thick skin and sweet taste, making it easy to transport and popular. United Fruit, the biggest banana grower in South America, grew many bananas by cloning parts of the banana plant, not by seeds. They grew the plants very close together in large fields.

original: Spider venom is present in most species and serves the purpose of stunning or killing their prey rather than attacking humans. In fact, only 25 of the known spider species produce venom which can actually harm humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly. Australia's notorious Sydney funnel-web spider has not produced any fatalities since anti-venom was developed in 1981. However, take care not to rub hairy spiders like tarantulas up the wrong way. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.
simplified: Most spiders have venom to catch or kill their food, not to attack people. Only 25 types of spiders have venom that can hurt humans. Spider bites can hurt but they do not often cause death. In Australia, the Sydney funnel-web spider has not caused any deaths since a special medicine was made in 1981. But be careful with spiders like tarantulas. If they feel scared, they can throw tiny hairs into the air. These tiny hairs can get into your skin or eyes and cause irritation.

original: This horror film cliché was especially popular with horror films of the late 20th century. It starts with a group of teenagers all enjoying themselves, and it ends with everyone dead except one girl. At the beginning the girl is usually innocent, shy and not particularly strong. By the end, she has become the toughest and most resourceful person in the world. The last girl almost always wins in the end.
simplified: This common idea in horror films was very popular in the late 20th century. It starts with a group of teenagers having fun. But in the end, everyone is dead except one girl. At first, this girl is usually innocent, shy, and not very strong. By the end, she becomes the bravest and smartest person. The last girl almost always wins.

original: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
simplified: To understand how we developed complex language, we should look at how our brains are different from other animals. It's not just about brain size; it also matters what our brains can do and how they changed over time. We don't have many physical clues about this. The tools and objects our ancestors left behind don't show us how they spoke. But when we study early humans' bones, we can see changes in the mouth, throat, and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans could make complex sounds. Before this time, scientists can only guess if early humans used simple sounds to communicate.

original: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Coupled with this is the lack of positive female role models youngsters see doing science-related jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or adventurous astronaut as a man. Furthermore, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they may mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and see science as an unappealing career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified: Society, not nature, tells girls to like arts and humanities and lets boys do maths and physics. Also, there are not enough positive female role models in science for young people to see. Cartoons and stories often show scientists, inventors, or astronauts as men. People also think scientists are geeky, have bad social skills, or work alone, away from everyone. These are not true, but they can make girls feel like science is not for them. If girls saw more female role models in science, it might help them feel more confident and interested in science.

original: The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free in faculty buildings, with a readership of approximately 10,000 students. It is written and produced entirely by students. The survey shows that the newspaper is highly valued by university students and staff for entertainment, cultural enrichment and work experience. The cost of printing newspapers is significant. Furthermore, some students do not have easy access to the paper, since the only way to obtain a copy is to physically go to university. An additional environmental issue is that a large number of copies end up as litter on campus.
simplified: The Scallion is a newspaper that comes out every week. You can find it for free in university buildings where professors work. Around 10,000 students read it. Students write and make the newspaper. People at the university like it for fun, learning about culture, and helping students get job experience. Printing the newspaper is expensive. Also, some students have trouble getting it because they must be on campus to pick one up. Another problem is that many newspapers are thrown away and make the campus messy.

original: At Girox Foods, we are experiencing an annual employee turnover of about 12 per cent. Although this might not seem high at first glance, the industry standard is seven per cent. The principal objective of this report is to investigate the causes of employee engagement within the firm and, based on those, offer recommendations to improve the employees' experience of the workplace and increase employee retention.
simplified: At Girox Foods, about 12 out of every 100 workers leave each year. At first, this may not look like a lot, but most companies like ours only have about 7 out of 100 workers leave each year. The main goal of this report is to find out why employees like working here and then give advice on how to make their work experience better so they want to stay longer.

original: So much of what the speaker said rang true. I honestly believe there's a danger that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. I don't think this is such an issue for my generation who've lived without technology for so long. We know how to be alone and, more importantly, we know that it's OK to be alone. But the under 20s are another kettle of fish. They're so busy communicating that they never experience the feeling of solitude and run the risk of not learning how to enjoy their own company. In addition, they're learning conversation through messages that can be edited and changed at the expense of learning the art of real conversation in real time with the person in front of you.
simplified: Much of what the speaker said felt true to me. I think there is a risk that the more we connect with others through technology, the more alone we feel. This is not a big problem for my generation because we lived a long time without much technology. We know how to be alone and that being alone is okay. But people under 20 are different. They are always talking to others, so they never feel how it is to be alone. They might not learn to enjoy spending time by themselves. Also, they learn to talk by sending messages, where they can change what they say. This means they might not learn how to have conversations with people face-to-face.

original: Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the positives can become devalued and ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given for its own sake and resist the temptation to offer constructive criticism.
simplified: Do not always give negative feedback after positive feedback. If you always give both, people might stop caring about the positive feedback. Sometimes, just give positive feedback and do not add any criticism.

original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.
simplified: Your dreams can show you things you didn't know you were thinking about. Common dreams, like flying, falling, losing your teeth, or being naked in public, usually have similar meanings for most people. However, to understand what your dreams mean for you, you need to connect them to what happens in your daily life and how you feel.

original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.
simplified: One of the most interesting examples of wild animals living in a city is the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are about 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of these dogs were born in the wild, while others were pets that their owners left behind. Some dogs live by themselves, and others live in groups. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and discovered that they have adapted very well to life in the city. They have learned it is safer to cross the street with people, and some dogs seem to understand traffic lights.

original: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. Wonder has been a bestseller in the United States and has already won several awards. Many schools are using it as a starting point for discussions about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A film version is being made, and many, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.
simplified: Wonder is the first novel by RJ Palacio, who is from New York. On her website, she says that she got the idea for the book after seeing a girl with a different-looking face on the street one day. Wonder has become very popular in the United States and has won several prizes. Many schools are using it to start conversations about bullying, friendship, and being different from others. A movie is being made based on the book, and many people, including me, are excited to see what RJ Palacio will write next.

original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.
simplified: Chloe has two pet rats named Zena and Roxy. She knows that not everyone thinks of rats as pets and has explained many times that rats are not dirty. She says they make great pets if you take care of them properly. Chloe understands why some people don't like rats, because she felt the same way at first. But then her friend Martin showed her his pet rats, and she saw that they were loving and smart. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided to take two of them as her own pets.

original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.
simplified: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some baboons have been hurt or killed in car accidents, and others have been electrocuted when they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species, which means there are not many of them left. To help save them and reduce problems between people and baboons, the city council has hired Baboon Monitors. These monitors have the job of making baboons leave the city or catching them and letting them go in the countryside. This has helped a little, but it is still difficult to stop baboons from coming back to the city because they find it easy to get food there.

original: I work for a global IT company, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making idle chit-chat with colleagues. I work on a project basis, and this flexibility is very valuable to me because it means that I can easily take some time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. The downside is that without clear office hours, I tend to work well into the evening, sometimes skipping dinner to finish a task.
simplified: I work for a big IT company, but their main office is in the USA, so I do all my work online from home. This means I don't spend time traveling to work or talking with my colleagues without a purpose. I work on different projects, and this flexibility is very important to me because I can easily take a break when my children need me at their school performances, or if I need to go to the dentist. The negative part is that, without set office hours, I often end up working late into the evening and sometimes skip dinner to finish my work.

original: In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to make political points and produced art that tried to make people think about war, inequality and discrimination. Other street artists were more concerned with producing beautiful, attractive work. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas adding colour, life and beauty to grey, city walls.
simplified: In the 1990s, graffiti was still popular, but street art also started to appear everywhere in the world. Some artists used street art to talk about political issues like war, inequality, and discrimination. They wanted people to think about these problems. Other street artists focused on creating beautiful and eye-catching art. In South America, many street artists worked in poor areas. They added color, life, and beauty to the grey walls of the cities.

original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it is easy for customers to buy without thinking, while major brands offer such cheap clothes that they can be treated like disposable items – worn two or three times and then thrown away.
simplified: Every day, social media, magazines, and shop windows show us many things to buy, and people in the UK are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. With online shopping, it is easy for people to buy things quickly, without much thought. Big brands sell clothes at very low prices, so people often wear them only a few times before throwing them away.

original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr, Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning ruddy in the June sun. Otherwise he had the indoor tan of a man that made money while other people did the work.
simplified: Sam looked carefully at the car making a line of dust as it drove towards the Big House. The horses moved their tails to avoid flies and didn't care that their owner was visiting for the first time in ten months. Sam waited. Mr. Carter only came here when necessary, which was okay with Sam. The less Sam saw of his boss, the longer he could keep his job. Mr. Carter wiped the sweat from his neck because the sun was hot in June. The damp spots on his shirt looked like shapes on a map. His skin was getting red from the sun, but he usually looked like someone who worked indoors while others did the hard work.

original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.
simplified: Many people living in Berlin, Germany were upset about hunters shooting pigs, saying it was too cruel. There were a lot of arguments between the hunters and people who care about animals. Because of these protests, the city council chose to try a kinder way to deal with the pigs. They decided to put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs instead of shooting them. We will see if this plan will work, but it might be hard because warmer winters mean there are more pigs now than before.

original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. original: Businesses have caught on to the profitability of the sharing economy and are seeking to gain from making use of those underutilised resources. original: One of the most important modern functions of zoos is supporting international breeding programmes, particularly for endangered species. In the wild, some of the rarest species have difficulty in finding mates and breeding, and they might also be threatened by poachers, loss of their habitat and predators. A good zoo will enable these species to live and breed in a secure environment. In addition, as numbers of some wild species drop, there is an increased danger of populations becoming too genetically similar. Breeding programmes provide a safeguard: zoo-bred animals can be released into the wild to increase genetic diversity.
simplified: One of the most important jobs of zoos today is to help with breeding programs around the world, especially for animals that are endangered. In the wild, some very rare animals have trouble finding mates and having babies. They are also in danger from hunters, losing their homes, and other animals that hunt them. A good zoo helps these animals live and have babies in a safe place. Also, when the numbers of some wild animals go down, there is a risk that they all become too similar genetically. Breeding programs help with this problem by letting animals born in zoos go back into the wild. This helps to make sure there is more genetic variety in the wild animals.

original: Both of these kinds of accidents are extremely rare, but boats and trains can cause a bridge to collapse for different reasons. With boats, it's the very large mass they have that can bring about the collapse, even if they are moving very slowly when it occurs. The best way to avoid bridge failures is to plan for them. simplified: It is very uncommon for bridges to collapse because of trains or boats, but it can happen in different ways. When a train hits a bridge, its speed can make the bridge fall. For a boat, even if it moves slowly, its big size can cause a bridge to collapse. To stop these accidents, we should plan and prepare. We can use new technology to find weak spots in structures, make safer workplaces, and use better designs to help stop these accidents from happening.

original: Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. In one study, most happy people were found to have strong ties to friends and family and they made sure they spent time with them regularly. You also need at least one person who you discuss personal feelings with – called 'self-disclosure'. Just one person for a heart-to-heart is enough, together with a network of other relationships. It's not enough to have lots of friends just to do things with or chat to about music or football. That deeper connection is all-important. Some people need to learn how to listen effectively to others in order to develop stronger relationships.
simplified: Having good relationships helps us be happy. In a study, most happy people had close connections with their friends and family, and they made sure to spend time with them often. original: Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck spoke of the plasticity of the brain and our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to focus our praise on the end result and seemingly innate talents, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research suggests that by focusing on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation and problem-solving strategies – we can encourage the development of new skills and the continued honing of talents.
simplified: Psychologist Carol Dweck, who supports the idea of a 'growth mindset', talked about how our brains can change and how we can learn new skills, even if we weren't good at them before. Many people often praise the final result or natural talents, saying things like 'You are really good at noticing details' or 'You are great at organizing events'. But research shows that if we focus on how things are done, like praising effort, trying new things, and solving problems, we can help people learn new skills and get even better at what they do.

original: The rover analyses the air around it periodically, and in 2014 it found the air contained another of the most basic organic molecules and a key ingredient of natural gas: methane. According to NASA, Mars emits thousands of tons of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls at seasonal intervals in the year, almost as if the planet is breathing it.
simplified: The rover checks the air around it from time to time, and in 2014, it discovered that the air had methane, one of the simplest organic molecules and an important part of natural gas. original: Early in her career, the psychologist Carol Dweck of Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-olds problems that were slightly too hard for them. One group reacted positively, said they loved challenge and understood that their abilities could be developed. She says they had a 'growth mindset' and are focused on what they can achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and were unable to imagine improving. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.
simplified: At the start of her career, psychologist Carol Dweck from Stanford University gave some ten-year-old kids problems that were a bit too difficult for them. One group of kids reacted well. They loved the challenge and knew they could get better. Dweck calls this a 'growth mindset' because these kids focus on what they can do in the future. Another group of kids thought their intelligence was being tested and felt like they failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and couldn't see how they might improve. Some of these kids said they might cheat next time, and others wanted to find someone who did worse than them to feel better about themselves.

original: Horror films love uninhabited places. This could be an abandoned hospital, a scary empty house or a ghost town. There's something about lonely, empty places. simplified: Horror movies often use empty places like old hospitals, scary houses, or towns with no people. These empty places are useful for making horror films because it's easy to believe that you won't have phone service there.

original: The majority of people believe that developing countries are in a terrible situation: suffering from incredible poverty, governed by dictators and with little hope for any meaningful change.
