original: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when feedback becomes such a routine, employees can start to perceive positive feedback as simply a form of sugarcoating the negatives, thus diminishing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered so as to reinforce and encourage good performance.
simplified: Many managers try to make their feedback more positive by placing a negative comment between two positive ones. But when they do this all the time, employees might start to think that the positive feedback is just a way to soften the bad news. This can make the positive feedback feel less important. Instead, positive feedback should be used to support and encourage good work, not just to make bad feedback sound nicer.

original: I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. simplified: I am part of a group called the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Don't think about scary movie robots like the Terminator. original: Your manager stops you and says she needs to have a word about your performance in the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. simplified: Are things getting worse each day? Is progress impossible? In his book 'Enlightenment Now', Steven Pinker looks at the overall picture of human progress and finds positive news. original: In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. original: Spider venom is present in most species and serves the purpose of stunning or killing their prey rather than attacking humans. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.
simplified: Most spiders have venom, which they use to catch their food, not to hurt people. Out of all the spider species, only 25 types have venom that can harm humans. Although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly. In Australia, the Sydney funnel-web spider was dangerous, but there have been no deaths from it since a medicine called anti-venom was made in 1981. Be careful when near hairy spiders like tarantulas. If they feel threatened, they can release tiny irritating hairs that stick to the skin or eyes of anything they think is an enemy.

original: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
simplified: To understand how we developed complex language skills, we need to explore how our brains are different from those of animals. It's not just about brain size; it's important to consider what else our brains can do and how they have changed over time. Unfortunately, there aren't many physical signs to help us with this, as ancient objects do not show what kind of language our ancestors used. However, by looking at early human remains, we can see changes in the mouth, throat, and tongue. Around 100,000 years ago, humans gained the ability to make complex sounds. Before this, scientists can only guess if early humans used simpler sounds to communicate.

original: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified: Society, not nature, often tells us that girls should like arts and humanities more than maths and physics, which are for boys. original: So much of what the speaker said rang true. I honestly believe there's a danger that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. simplified: I agree with much of what the speaker said. I think that the more we use technology to stay in touch, the more alone we might feel.
